ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Because I studied remote this semester, I participate in the lab virtually. But I had a lab group member who was in-person doing the experiments themselves. I was able to control the computer through Zoom while they set up the various equipment. We also had pre-lab lectures that were recorded and posted to the media library on Canvas.
Combination of virtual lab and in-person lab. Since I was at home instead of New Haven, I was fully virtual.

Some in-person labs and one virtual lab
Additional lectures/tutorials were posted on Canvas
Attended lab via zoom
None
N/A
virtual lab with in-person component for those on campus.
Students not on campus were able to participate virtually.
We had in person lab every other week with some lab partners joining virtually and screen sharing while the in person partners were physically at the lab station.
In-person lab or virtual lab, depending on student's choice.
In-person

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Applications of Biomedical Engineering (5 labs related to Biosignals, Electrocardiography, Neuromusclar System, Respiratory System, Bone Biomechanics)
I learned about many physiological lab techniques, and how to interpret readings from devices that I did not have any familiarity with.
Learned a lot about signals and measurements
Application of biomedical engineering concepts to practice.

Practiced data acquisition and collection utilizing MatLab. 
Practiced analyzing data.
Further explored the human body outside of the classroom/textbook context (albeit remotely).
I gained practical experience about how things I had learnt in class translated to real life.

We used a MATLAB GUI to collect data from 5 different labs that spanned the human body. We later analyzed and extrapolated from this data when writing our lab reports. We learned about the neuromuscular system by shocking each other and watching our thumbs twitch, we broke chicken bones to learn bone mechanics, we used ECG on each other to understand the cardiovascular system, and we looked at data collected from respirators to understand lungs.

I do feel like I learned a lot about measuring biological signals and some basic processing. The lab itself is pretty simple/easy but the lab reports were more complicated/challenging and I think are what really contributed to my learning.
Learned about physiology in the context of lab.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual format was a bit difficult to handle, especially for a lab class like this that involved a lot of hands-on work. However, the faculty did a great job of allowing virtual students like myself to feel engaged. I was able to participate on the digital side as my lab group member in person set everything up.

Strengths: The teaching staff were all very nice, and did not hesitate to clear up confusions that we had on assignments as long as we emailed them in a timely manner. Also, even though I was remote, I was still able to remotely control screens for one of the experiments so I did not feel completely detached.

Weaknesses: It took 4 weeks for our first lab report to be graded, so I didn't know what they would be looking for until I had already submitted two lab reports. This was 20% of my grade, so knowing what I could do to improve my reports (i.e. the TAs grading faster) at a sooner time would have definitely helped.
Grading for lab reports could have been more explicit

Strengths: Very hands-on, collaborative, and engaging. The topics of the labs were also really interesting. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes it was unclear as to what we were supposed to be doing, and if our results were correct. Physiological data is very messy and variable, so maybe it would be beneficial to have your graphs/results checked before leaving lab. It was hard to write lab reports without knowing if your data was correct or not. The respiratory lab was remote (for obvious reasons), but the data given to us was pretty messy, and we didn't know how to interpret it. More instruction and guidance would have been helpful.
Content was interesting. Some of the labs were unnecessarily tedious.

Labs were fun to do, and awesome for applying the knowledge I had learned before! I thought that report workload could be a little high at times, especially the lung lab; even though we didn't do the data gathering, the interpretation and processing of the data took me a long time. The final was more difficult than I expected; I felt like it should have been open note, given the amount of content it was covering/the fact that this was a lab and not a content class. Lastly, some of the questions on the reports were confusing/not clear; I thought I was answering them correctly, so I didn't ask the TA's, but found out on my grading that they were wrong.

TA's gave quick and efficient feedback. Labs were well-explained and fairly graded!

Strengths: interesting studies (I especially like the EKG lab).
Weaknesses: I feel like some of the lab report manuals could be adapted for the COVID environment to be more clear for those working virtually to understand the actual lab procedure. There were also some parts of the lab procedures that were a bit hard to understand for my in-person lab partners so a bit more clarity would help!

Since I was remote, I felt like the lab could be a little more engaging. For the most part, it was mostly my group members performing the lab procedure while I followed along. There wasn't really a lot of space for discussion or anything interactive.

The lab reports were the most helpful for grasping the focus of the lab. I really enjoyed it and learned a lot. It was not an overwhelming amount of work. It would be helpful to see sample data after we leave lab to compare with our own to determine if we had made an accidental error. Our results shape our reasoning as well as vice versa, and we could have saved some time going down rabbit holes by knowing if our data was even accurate to begin with.
The intensity of the lab reports don't line up with the lab.  It could be improved if the lab or prelab lecture was more in depth.

This is a virtual lab course, and I felt it did not do enough to aid the virtual students, and those of us that were virtual ended up at a large disadvantage to those in person. The lab report questions were not clear at all and need to be more specific, and people were largely unresponsive in terms of advice for the reports.

Strength: Labs were really engaging and the types of labs were fun.
Weakness: Lab grading was often harsh and not clear in what was being looked for.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The use of Zoom to remotely control the computer in the lab was very helpful in allowing the virtual students to partake in the lab instead of just sitting and watching. 
I think it would've been helpful to have the pre-lab lectures live through Zoom, instead of pre-recorded, so that students could hear questions from other students and get a better understanding of the material covered in each lab.

I think the hybrid in-person and online format of the course is unfair to those who are in person. I personally was fully online, but I recognize that I saved myself the trouble of actually showing up to class and doing most of the "grunt" work for the experiments. If the class were to be offered again, to make it more fair for the in-person students, all labs should be fully virtual.
It was really great to have an in-person component

It was really nice having the prelab lecture posted on canvas before lab to watch. Additionally, I think it was successful to have ~2 groups in lab at one time. This not only allowed for social distancing, but it also allowed for greater interaction with the professors/TAs and a better learning environment.
Remote option was good, a little difficult at times when remote control over the computer was finnicky.
I really liked being able to perform experiments in person; this was a highlight of my week, and I never felt unsafe!

Success: integrating the virtual students into the lab! It was actually a better experience than I imagined. I think the hybrid groups with at least one in-lab individual per group was effective.
Weaknesses: some lab procedures were hard to understand (as stated above) and virtual engagement was tough just given the nature of labs. Perhaps coming up with some alternative ways in which virtual students could be more helpful during the actual lab session could benefit those learning remotely. However, I know that this is a very broad suggestion and would probably be hard to implement.

All in all, I believe the course was a success in the COVID environment.
Having virtual labs was great but maybe for the ones where students did not go into the labs maybe there could be some virtual simulations lab instead.
It was helpful to allow some of us to go in person to collect the data ourselves rather than simply analyze data and watch someone else do it. Great feedback on our lab reports!
This is a virtual lab course, and I felt it did not do enough to aid the virtual students, and those of us that were virtual ended up at a large disadvantage to those in person.

The in-person / online group setup worked generally fine. The in-person group definitely gets to have more practice handling equipment but a big part of learning comes from analyzing the data after lab as well, which doesn't require in-person attendance.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I'd recommend it to other BME majors as well as those taking pre-med requirements because it gives a nice overview of various systems in the body.

If you are considering taking this course, you are likely a BENG major who needs to take it. I personally did not like the course at first, but then once I started getting the hang of how things worked in BENG 355L, it wasn't that bad. This semester it was also nice that we only had class session and an assignment due every two weeks. It was a little stressful that we only had one week to complete our lab reports instead of two weeks like normal, but it was nice having a pretty lenient class in terms of showing up.

Yes. Compared to gen chem/physics labs, this lab is so much more engaging and relevant. The labs are quite fun; however, the lab reports are often unnecessarily complicated. They aren't super long, which is nice, but the questions they ask are often difficult to explain with the data collected in lab.
Only if you have to take it. The lab reports were graded somewhat harshly.
You probably have to take it, but it won't burn your brains out. Format is good - once every other week is fair for a half-credit course. Lab reports are a bit of work and definitely require thought.
This is a requirement at least for the BME major. I would say take it if you need it.
Absolutely! Biomedical engineering majors are required to take this course, and you will all enjoy it a lot. It does not have to be taken concurrently with physio.
Only if you need to take it, would probably be a better experience in person.
Yes, I think this course is really great. The grading is unpredictable, but I think that depends on the TA.
